qas.question: What was a benefit to broadcasters of recording standards?
How did the NBC Othacoustic curve relate to the NAB curve?
What bass settings were needed to eliminate hum?
What helped cause the most life like sound?

context: The lateral cut NAB curve was <a1_0>remarkably similar<a1_0/> to the NBC Orthacoustic curve that evolved from practices within the National Broadcasting Company since the mid-1930s. Empirically, and not by any formula, it was learned that the bass end of the audio spectrum <a2_0>below 100 Hz<a2_0/> could be boosted somewhat to override system hum and turntable rumble noises. Likewise at the treble end beginning at 1,000 Hz, if audio frequencies were boosted by 16 dB at 10,000 Hz the delicate sibilant sounds of speech and high overtones of musical instruments could survive the noise level of cellulose acetate, lacquer/aluminum, and vinyl disc media.
